entry.title: All My Life I Have Wanted Word Magnets
entry.content:
since my first encounter with them, on the fridge of my friend's house. They always read something mysterious and vaguely gorgeous about petunias. I always passed them before retrieving ramen for snacktime and ached to rearrange a verb or two. When I later tried searching for them, I discovered with dismay that they were like twenty dollars.

Twenty dollars. Seriously. At the time that was an entire month's allowance.

Now it's roughly equivalent to two restaurant meals. Which means word magnets are justifiable if I balance them out with a lunch/dinner of oranges and/or English muffins with avocados or peanut butter.

The best part was that the "base" set came in a steel container, which is both carrying case and easel. I also ended up grabbing the "haiku" set, because I wanted nature-y words like "autumn" and "cloud."

it's so deep

I adore the constraint of word magnets; I love how the pattern-finding human mind can glimpse words into meaningful fragments. Sometimes I'm tempted to place aside some of the word-appendages (a, the, ly, ed, d, etc.) just so that I can retrieve them easier when I know I'm looking for, but somehow to simplify the process of digging would taint the spontaneity that is the point of word magnets (to me).

word magnets on the ferry

Word magnets also, I think, lend one practice to two things I've personally wanted to improve on to strengthen my writing: verbs that hoist sentences onto their shoulders (and off the backs of adjectives/adverbs), and conciseness.

entry.title: Cool Things Learned Today From the Internet
entry.content:
Tree rot

happens when a tree sustains a large wound near or on its trunk and fungus moves in before the tree can "callous" over the hurt area. The fungus eat away at the wood fiber, but some trees (like oak) can remain structurally sound by "compartmentalizing the decay," or allowing the fungus to eat away only at the wood that is already dead at the tree's center, and not at the tree's new growth rings. Some trees can even develop a "rams-horn," which is when tree growth curves inward. This keeps the tree standing sturdy. (via Austin Tree Experts)

...party on the inside
photo by Randy Cyr, Greentree, Bugwood.org (source)


Horsetail Fall

is a waterfall in Yosemite National Park which, once a year during a sunset in the last week of February, becomes illuminated by sunlight and becomes a "natural firefall." (via NPR: From Waterfall To Lavafall: Yosemite's Fleeting Phenomenon)

by Joe Azure, used through CC (source)

Octopi

die soon after performing what needs to be done to ensure the birth of new octopi. In the male's case, this means doling out sperm; in the female's case, it means after laying globby strings of eggs and guarding them for about a month, during which she will not hunt and may ingest her own legs for sustenance. (via Wikipedia)
